ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Someone said or implied that all LGBQ people have the same experiences.
I was told I should act ''less lesbian, gay, bisexual, or queer.''
People said or implied that I was being overly sensitive for thinking I was treated poorly or unfairly because I am LGBQ.
Someone told me they were praying for me because they knew or assumed I am lesbian, gay, bisexual, or queer.
People seemed willing to tolerate my LGBQ identity but were not willing to talk about it.
Others thought I would not have kids because they knew or assumed I am lesbian, gay, bisexual, or queer.
Someone said they couldn't be homophobic, biphobic, or queerphobic because they have (a) lesbian, gay, bisexual, or queer friend(s).
I was told that being lesbian, gay, bisexual, or queer is ''just a phase.''
Straight people assumed that I would come on to them because they thought or knew I am lesbian, gay, bisexual, or queer.
I have heard people say that they were tired of hearing about the ''homosexual agenda.''
Someone said or implied that LGBQ people engage in unsafe sex because of their sexual orientation.
Other people said, ''that's just the way it is'' when I voiced frustration about homophobia, biphobia, or queerphobia.
Someone said or implied that my sexual orientation is a result of something that went ''wrong'' in my past (e.g., ''your mother was too overbearing'').
People assumed that I have a lot of sex because of my sexual orientation.
Others have said that LGBQ people should not be around children.
I saw negative messages about LGBQ people on social media (e.g., Facebook, Twitter) posted by contacts or organizations, or in advertisements.
In my school/workplace it was OK to make jokes about LGBQ people.
I heard someone say ''that's so gay'' to describe something as negative, stupid, or uncool.
I received information about sexual health that was limited to heterosexual sex.
